value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There is an entry in <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-phen" key="Henslowe, Philip">Henslowes</rs> diary, which</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Henslowe in      had jotted down in his diary the cost of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the lathe, the nails, the timber that he had</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">bought. For painting the theatre</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and for the clothes worn by the play Hens–</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>that was the house that</del> the playhouse</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was being built on the Banks of the Thames.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But how far was the author <add place="above">playwright</add> in 1570 separate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> the minstrel, the ballad singer?</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The past seems to be that, when Spenser</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Attached his name to the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Fairy Queen</rs>, the author of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-span" key="Spanish Tragedy, The">The Spanish Tragedy</rs> left his work gu unsigned</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">This is a sign <del>of the</del> that there were two publics:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the reading, & the playgoing. <del>There is a division</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It marks a distinction between two kinds of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">writer – two methods, <del>too</del> two attitudes of mind.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">If there had been no minstrel, would English literature </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">had remained a read, a book literature?</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">No stage, no common art; but always one book to be</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">read, privately; –</l>
